⁶ Trebatius was patronus of Ulubrae, and during his absence had left Cicero in charge of his clients there. Being near the Pomptine marshes, Ulubrae was overrun with frogs, and Cicero pretends that they were the clients Tre- batius had made over to him.

⁶ He refers to the great rising in Gaul in 54 and 53, and the second expedition across the Rhine.

⁶ Cicero, disgusted with the state of affairs under Antony, is now on his way to Goeece, and sends this letter (dated eight days later than the next) from Rhegium on the coast of Bruttium, whither he had sailed from Velia in Lucania, where Trebatius had a house, occupied by Cicero in his absence.
